ch1.chapterOverview: Chapter 1 of Biology class 10 explores the various life processes that are essential for the survival and functioning of living organisms. It covers topics such as nutrition, respiration, transportation, excretion, and reproduction. The chapter emphasizes the importance of these processes in maintaining the overall health and well-being of organisms.

content.example: Substances required by the body for growth, maintenance, and energy production, including carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, and water
Autotrophic nutrition (photosynthesis) and heterotrophic nutrition (ingestion, digestion, absorption)
The organ system involved in the breakdown of food into smaller, soluble molecules that can be absorbed and utilized by the body
The process of releasing energy from food through a series of chemical reactions, such as aerobic respiration and anaerobic respiration
The organ system responsible for the transport of substances (such as nutrients, oxygen, carbon dioxide, hormones) throughout the body
Tubes that carry blood, including arteries, veins, and capillaries
The muscular organ that pumps blood and maintains the circulation in the body
The organ system involved in the elimination of waste products (such as urea, carbon dioxide, excess water) from the body
The organs responsible for filtering blood and producing urine
The organ system comprising the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra, involved in the formation and elimination of urine
The organ system involved in the production of offspring, including the male and female reproductive organs
Reproduction without the involvement of gametes, resulting in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent
Reproduction involving the fusion of gametes (sperm and egg), resulting in offspring with genetic variation
The monthly cycle of changes in the female reproductive system, including the release of an egg and preparation of the uterus for pregnancy

ch2.chapterOverview: Chapter 2 of Biology class 10 explores the concept of control and coordination in living organisms. It covers topics such as the nervous system, the endocrine system, the coordination between these systems, and the mechanisms by which organisms respond to various stimuli. The chapter emphasizes the importance of maintaining homeostasis and adaptability in organisms.

content.example: Specialized cells that transmit nerve impulses and form the basis of the nervous system
The part of the nervous system that includes the brain and spinal cord, responsible for processing and integrating information
The part of the nervous system that consists of nerves and ganglia outside the CNS, responsible for transmitting signals between the CNS and the rest of the body
An involuntary and rapid response to a stimulus, mediated by the spinal cord without involving the brain
Chemical messengers produced by endocrine glands and released into the bloodstream, regulating various bodily functions
Specialized organs that produce and secrete hormones, such as the pituitary gland, thyroid gland, adrenal glands, etc.
A region of the brain that controls the release of hormones from the pituitary gland and regulates body temperature, hunger, thirst, etc.
A regulatory process in which the output or response of a system influences the input or stimulus, maintaining homeostasis

topics.title: Coordination Between Nervous and Endocrine Systems

content.example: The cooperative interaction between the nervous and endocrine systems to regulate and coordinate bodily functions
Cells that have specific receptors for a particular hormone, allowing them to respond to hormonal signals
Chemical messengers released by neurons to transmit signals across synapses
A regulatory mechanism in which the response of a system inhibits or reverses the initial stimulus, maintaining stability
The growth or movement of an organism in response to external stimuli, such as phototropism (response to light) or gravitropism (response to gravity)
Non-directional responses of plants to stimuli, such as thigmonasty (response to touch) or nyctinasty (response to light-dark cycles)
A process by which an organism becomes less responsive to a repeated or constant stimulus over time

ch3.chapterOverview: Chapter 3 of Biology class 10 explores the different modes and mechanisms of reproduction in organisms. It covers topics such as sexual reproduction, asexual reproduction, and the significance of reproduction in maintaining species continuity. The chapter emphasizes the diversity of reproductive strategies and their adaptations to different environmental conditions.

content.example: Reproduction without the involvement of gametes, resulting in offspring that are genetically identical or similar to the parent
A form of asexual reproduction in which an organism divides into two daughter cells of equal size
A form of asexual reproduction in which a new individual develops as an outgrowth or bud from the parent organism
The ability of an organism to regrow lost or damaged body parts, resulting in the formation of a new individual
Reproduction involving the fusion of gametes (sperm and egg), resulting in offspring with genetic variation
Haploid reproductive cells (sperm and egg) that fuse during sexual reproduction to form a zygote
The fusion of sperm and egg to form a zygote, initiating the development of a new individual
The transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of a flower, enabling fertilization in plants
The reproductive structure of flowering plants, consisting of various parts (sepals, petals, stamens, carpels) involved in pollination and fertilization
Microscopic structures containing the male gametes (sperm) of flowering plants
The female gametophyte of flowering plants, containing the egg cell and other cells necessary for fertilization
The process of development and maturation of a seed following fertilization in flowering plants
The state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being in all matters relating to the reproductive system
The deliberate use of methods or devices to prevent pregnancy or sexually transmitted infections
Infections transmitted through sexual contact, such as HIV/AIDS, gonorrhea, syphilis, etc.
The monthly cycle in females characterized by the release of an egg from the ovary and preparation of the uterus for potential pregnancy

ch4.chapterOverview: Chapter 4 of Biology class 10 explores the concepts of heredity and evolution. It covers topics such as the principles of inheritance, genetic variations, natural selection, and the mechanisms of evolution. The chapter emphasizes the role of genetic factors and environmental influences in shaping the traits and diversity of living organisms.

content.example: The passing on of traits or characteristics from parents to offspring through genes
Segments of DNA that carry genetic information and determine specific traits in an organism
A trait that is expressed or observed when present in the genotype, represented by a capital letter
A trait that is expressed only when two copies of the recessive allele are present in the genotype, represented by a lowercase letter
Differences or diversity in traits or characteristics among individuals of the same species
A sudden change or alteration in the DNA sequence of a gene, resulting in new genetic variations
Abnormalities or diseases caused by mutations or inherited genetic factors
External factors, such as diet, climate, or lifestyle, that can affect the expression of genetic traits
The process of gradual change in the inherited traits of populations over successive generations
The mechanism by which certain advantageous traits are more likely to be passed on to future generations, while unfavorable traits are eliminated
The process by which organisms develop traits that enhance their survival and reproduction in specific environments
The formation of new species through the accumulation of genetic variations and reproductive isolation
The preserved remains or traces of organisms from past geological ages, providing evidence of past life forms and evolutionary changes
Structures that have a common origin but may have different functions in different organisms, indicating a shared ancestry
Structures that have similar functions but different origins, indicating convergent evolution
Similarities in the early developmental stages of different organisms, suggesting common ancestry
Similarities in the genetic code, proteins, and metabolic pathways among different organisms, indicating common ancestry

ch5.chapterOverview: Chapter 5 of Biology class 10 focuses on understanding the environment and its various components. It covers topics such as ecosystems, food chains and webs, biodiversity, and conservation of natural resources. The chapter emphasizes the interdependence between living organisms and their surroundings, as well as the importance of sustainable practices for environmental preservation.

content.example: A community of organisms interacting with each other and their physical environment
Living components of an ecosystem, including plants, animals, and microorganisms
Non-living components of an ecosystem, such as sunlight, temperature, water, soil, and air
Organisms that produce their own food through photosynthesis or chemosynthesis, forming the base of the food chain
Organisms that obtain energy by consuming other organisms
A linear sequence of organisms, where each organism serves as a source of food for the next organism
The different levels in a food chain or food web, including producers, primary consumers, secondary consumers, and so on
A complex network of interconnected food chains that represents the feeding relationships in an ecosystem
Organisms that break down dead organic matter and recycle nutrients back into the ecosystem
The variety of life forms, including species diversity, genetic diversity, and ecosystem diversity
A group of individuals that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring
Species that are at risk of extinction due to low population numbers or habitat destruction
The sustainable management and protection of natural resources and ecosystems to preserve biodiversity
Natural resources that can be replenished or regenerated over time, such as solar energy, wind energy, and water
Natural resources that are limited in supply and cannot be easily replenished, such as fossil fuels and minerals
Development that meets the needs of the present generation without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs
The process of converting waste materials into reusable materials to reduce resource consumption and environmental impact

ch6.chapterOverview: Chapter 6 of Biology class 10 focuses on the sustainable management of natural resources. It covers topics such as the importance of natural resources, their conservation, and the responsible utilization of resources for long-term sustainability. The chapter emphasizes the need for efficient resource management to meet the needs of the present generation while ensuring the availability of resources for future generations.

content.example: Materials or substances present in the environment that are essential or useful to living organisms
Natural resources that can be replenished or regenerated over time, such as solar energy, wind energy, and water
Natural resources that are limited in supply and cannot be easily replenished, such as fossil fuels and minerals
Natural resources derived from living organisms, such as forests, wildlife, and fisheries
Natural resources derived from non-living components, such as air, water, minerals, and land
The sustainable management and protection of natural resources to ensure their long-term availability
Efforts to reduce water wastage, promote efficient water use, and protect water sources from pollution
Measures to protect and preserve forest ecosystems, promote sustainable logging practices, and prevent deforestation
Efforts to protect endangered species, preserve habitats, and prevent illegal hunting and wildlife trade
Methods to prevent soil erosion, maintain soil fertility, and promote sustainable agricultural practices
Development that meets the needs of the present generation without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs
The process of planting trees in areas where there were no forests to create new forest cover
The process of replanting trees in areas where forests have been cut down or destroyed
The collection and storage of rainwater for various purposes, such as irrigation and domestic use
The proper handling, treatment, and disposal of waste materials to minimize environmental pollution
Energy derived from sources that can be replenished naturally, such as solar energy, wind energy, and hydropower
Energy obtained from the sun through solar panels or solar thermal systems
Energy generated from the power of wind using wind turbines
Energy harnessed from the flow of water in rivers or the potential energy of stored water in dams
Energy obtained from organic matter, such as biomass, biofuels, and biogas
